content.thinking: Looking at this document, I can see two ID cards from Colombia: 1. First card (top): - "REPÚBLICA DE COLOMBIA" - "IDENTIFICACIÓN PERSONAL" - "CÉDULA DE CIUDADANÍA" - Number: 7.534.022 - Name: RESTREPO PEREZ, JORGE DIEGO - Has a photo and signature - Shows typical security features of a Colombian ID card 2. Second card (bottom): - Shows a birth date: 05-JUN-1960 - Location: ARMENIA (QUINDIO) - Shows height: 1.66 - Blood type: O+ - Gender: M (SEXO) - Shows fingerprint - Has a barcode - Date and place of expedition: 06-MAR-1979 ARMENIA This is clearly a Colombian personal identification document (Cédula de Ciudadanía). Both sides show typical characteristics of a CECRL document: - Individual identification document - Personal biographical data (birth date, place, blood type, gender, height) - Individual photo and signature references - Government-issued personal ID number with individual name - Security elements (holograms, barcodes, official seals) - Issued by Colombian government identification authority Let me extract the text I can see: REPÚBLICA DE COLOMBIA IDENTIFICACIÓN PERSONAL CÉDULA DE CIUDADANÍA NÚMERO 7.534.022 RESTREPO PEREZ APELLIDOS JORGE DIEGO NOMBRES FIRMA FECHA DE NACIMIENTO: 05-JUN-1960 ARMENIA (QUINDIO) LUGAR DE NACIMIENTO 1.66 ESTATURA O+ G.S. RH M SEXO 06-MAR-1979 ARMENIA FECHA Y LUGAR DE EXPEDICIÓN ÍNDICE DERECHO A-4600100-00132855-M-000753402-200812C2 0007382910A1 8170007486 I recognize this as an official government-issued identification card with comprehensive personal details and robust security features typical of Colombian national documentation.
